Comm-Shanghai-1909.name: Shanghai Opium Commission, 1909
Comm-Shanghai-1909.description: First international meeting to address the opium problem, held in response to criticism of the opium trade and the Opium Wars. Foundation for the 1912 Hague Convention.

Treaty-Hague-1912.name: International Opium Convention (Hague, 1912)
Treaty-Hague-1912.description: First international drug control treaty. Introduced restrictions on export of opium, morphine, cocaine, and heroin for medical and legitimate purposes only.
Treaty-Hague-1912.in_force: 28 June 1919 (globally incorporated into Treaty of Versailles)

Treaty-Geneva-1925a.name: Convention concerning the Manufacture of, Internal Trade in, and Use of Prepared Opium (Geneva, 1925)
Treaty-Geneva-1925a.description: Agreement controlling prepared opium for smoking, particularly focused on Far Eastern territories.

Treaty-Geneva-1925b.name: International Convention relating to Dangerous Drugs (Geneva, 1925)
Treaty-Geneva-1925b.description: League of Nations convention expanding controls on dangerous drugs beyond opium to include other narcotic substances.

Treaty-Geneva-1931.name: Convention for Limiting the Manufacture and Regulating the Distribution of Narcotic Drugs (Geneva, 1931)
Treaty-Geneva-1931.description: Introduced a statistical control system and limitation on manufacturing of narcotic drugs. Established the Permanent Central Opium Board (PCOB).

Treaty-Geneva-1936.name: Convention of 1936 for the Suppression of the Illicit Traffic in Dangerous Drugs
Treaty-Geneva-1936.description: First treaty to make certain drug offenses international crimes. Focused on criminalizing illicit drug trafficking. Led by International Police Commission (precursor to INTERPOL).

Treaty-LakeSuccess-1946.name: Lake Success Protocol 1946
Treaty-LakeSuccess-1946.description: Protocol amending earlier drug control conventions to transfer functions from the League of Nations to the United Nations after World War II.

Treaty-Paris-1948.name: Protocol bringing under International Control Drugs Outside of the Scope of the 1931 Convention
Treaty-Paris-1948.description: Extended international control to drugs not covered by the 1931 Convention. Established the Commission on Narcotic Drugs.

Treaty-UN-1961.name: UN Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs (1961)
Treaty-UN-1961.description: Consolidated all previous drug control treaties into a single instrument. Broadened scope to include cannabis and established the International Narcotics Control Board (INCB). Limits drug use to medical and scientific purposes.

Treaty-OAS-1971.name: Inter-American Convention on the Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (1971)
Treaty-OAS-1971.description: Regional OAS treaty for combating illicit drug trafficking in the Americas. Based on UN conventions from 1961 and 1971.

Treaty-Vienna-1971.name: Vienna Convention on Psychotropic Substances (1971)
Treaty-Vienna-1971.description: Extended international control to psychotropic substances including amphetamines, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, and psychedelics (LSD, MDMA). Established four schedules of control.

Treaty-UN-1972.name: Protocol amending the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, 1961
Treaty-UN-1972.description: Expanded the role of the INCB in relation to illicit production, use, and traffic in narcotic drugs.

Treaty-CAN-1985.name: Andean Community Decision 391 (1985)
Treaty-CAN-1985.description: CAN decision establishing common rules for drug control and cooperation among Andean countries in combating illicit drug trafficking.

Treaty-UN-1988.name: UN Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (1988)
Treaty-UN-1988.description: Comprehensive measures against drug trafficking including provisions on money laundering, precursor chemicals, and international cooperation. Strengthened enforcement provisions of earlier conventions.

Treaty-EU-2004.name: Council Framework Decision 2004/757/JHA
Treaty-EU-2004.description: EU framework decision laying down minimum provisions on the constituent elements of criminal acts and penalties in the field of illicit drug trafficking.

Framework-CAN.name: Andean Plan of Action on Drugs
Framework-CAN.description: Strategic framework for CAN member states to coordinate drug control policies, alternative development programs, and regional cooperation initiatives.

Body-OpiumCommittee.name: Opium Advisory Committee
Body-OpiumCommittee.description: League of Nations advisory body on opium control. Provided technical advice and monitoring for implementation of drug control treaties.

Body-PCOB.name: Permanent Central Opium Board (PCOB)
Body-PCOB.description: First international drug control monitoring body, established to supervise the statistical control system. Started operating in 1928, later merged into INCB in 1968.

Body-CND.name: Commission on Narcotic Drugs
Body-CND.description: Principal policymaking body of the UN on drug-related matters. Makes decisions on drug scheduling and reviews implementation of drug control conventions.

Body-CNB.name: Commission on Narcotics Board
Body-CNB.description: Precursor body to the International Narcotics Control Board. Part of the transition from League of Nations drug control system to UN system.

Body-WHO.name: World Health Organization (WHO)
Body-WHO.description: UN specialized agency responsible for international public health. Reviews substances for international control and makes scheduling recommendations to the Commission on Narcotic Drugs.

Body-OAS.name: Organization of American States (OAS)
Body-OAS.description: Regional international organization founded in 1948. Addresses drug issues through CICAD and promotes cooperation on drug control among 35 member states in the Americas.

Body-INCB.name: International Narcotics Control Board (INCB)
Body-INCB.description: Independent, quasi-judicial monitoring body for the implementation of UN drug control conventions. Monitors licit drug trade and works to prevent diversion. Merged PCOB and Drug Supervisory Body.

Body-CAN.name: Comunidad Andina de Naciones (CAN)
Body-CAN.description: South American trade bloc promoting economic and political integration among Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru. Originally founded as Andean Pact in 1969, reformed as CAN in 1997.
Body-CAN.in_force: 1969 (as Andean Pact), 1997 (as CAN per Trujillo Protocol)

Body-EuropeanCouncil.name: European Council
Body-EuropeanCouncil.description: Supreme political authority of the European Union, composed of heads of state or government of EU member states. Issues regulations and directives on drug control.

Body-CICAD.name: Inter-American Drug Abuse Control Commission (CICAD)
Body-CICAD.description: OAS specialized body serving as the hemisphere's policy forum on drug issues. Promotes multilateral cooperation, provides technical assistance, and operates the Multilateral Evaluation Mechanism (MEM).

Body-EMCDDA.name: European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA)
Body-EMCDDA.description: EU agency providing evidence-based information on drugs and drug addiction in Europe. Collects and analyzes data through the Reitox network of national focal points.

Body-UNODC.name: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC)
Body-UNODC.description: UN office responsible for coordinating international action against illicit drugs and crime. Assists countries in implementing drug control treaties.

PE-DL11005-1949.name: Criminal Code Reform - Decreto Ley 11005 (Peru)
PE-DL11005-1949.description: Early Peruvian drug control legislation reforming the criminal code to address narcotics offenses.

PE-Treaty-1964.name: Peru Ratification of Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs of 1961
PE-Treaty-1964.description: Peru's ratification of the UN Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs of 1961, committing to international drug control obligations.

PE-DL22095-1978.name: Law for the Suppression of Illegal Drug Trafficking - Decreto Ley 22095 (Peru)
PE-DL22095-1978.description: Comprehensive law establishing the legal framework for drug control in Peru. Objectives include repression of illicit drug trafficking, prevention of drug abuse, rehabilitation of addicts, and reduction of coca cultivation. Established ENACO S.A. as the state entity for legal coca industrialization.

PE-Treaty-1980.name: Peru Ratification of Convention on Psychotropic Substances of 1971
PE-Treaty-1980.description: Peru's ratification of the UN Convention on Psychotropic Substances of 1971, extending drug control to psychotropic substances.

PE-DL122-1981.name: Amendment to Drug Trafficking Law - Decreto Legislativo 122 (Peru)
PE-DL122-1981.description: Amendment to Decreto Ley 22095 modifying penalties and procedures for drug trafficking offenses. Introduced provisions for reduced sentences in cases of small quantities and personal addiction.

PE-Treaty-1990.name: Peru Ratification of Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances of 1988
PE-Treaty-1990.description: Peru's ratification of the UN Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances of 1988.

PE-CriminalCode-1991.name: Criminal Code (Peru)
PE-CriminalCode-1991.description: New criminal code that maintained strong repressive measures and high penalties for drug offenses. Removed criminal sanctions for personal use of drugs in small amounts but continued harsh penalties for trafficking.

PE-DL824-1996.name: Law to Fight Illicit Drug Trafficking - Decreto Legislativo 824 (Peru)
PE-DL824-1996.description: Law declaring the fight against drug consumption and trafficking as a matter of national interest. Strengthened penalties and enforcement mechanisms.

PE-Regulation-2001.name: Regulation of Controlled Narcotic and Psychotropic Substances (Peru)
PE-Regulation-2001.description: Regulation establishing controls over narcotic and psychotropic substances, including licensing and monitoring requirements.

PE-DL1126-2012.name: Law of Controlled Substances used in Illicit Drugs - Decreto Legislativo 1126 (Peru)
PE-DL1126-2012.description: Established measures to control chemical inputs, machinery, and equipment used in the production of illicit drugs. Part of efforts to strengthen security and defense strategy.

PE-DL1241-2015.name: Law to Strengthen Suppression of Illegal Drug Trafficking - Decreto Legislativo 1241 (Peru)
PE-DL1241-2015.description: Strengthened the fight against illicit drug trafficking and enhanced operational capacity of the National Police. Created the Drug Information System (SISCOD) and criminalized illegal coca replanting with 3-8 years imprisonment.

US-Harrison-1914.name: Harrison Narcotics Tax Act (United States)
US-Harrison-1914.description: First comprehensive federal drug control law in the United States. Regulated and taxed the production, importation, and distribution of opiates and coca products. Required registration with collectors of internal revenue and imposed special taxes on those dealing with narcotics.

US-Marihuana-1937.name: Marihuana Tax Act (United States)
US-Marihuana-1937.description: First federal regulation on cannabis in the United States. Placed a tax on the sale of cannabis and imposed registration and documentation requirements. Effectively prohibited marijuana through prohibitive taxation.

US-Boggs-1951.name: Boggs Act (United States)
US-Boggs-1951.description: Amended the Narcotic Drugs Import and Export Act to establish mandatory minimum sentences for drug convictions. First federal law to impose mandatory minimums for drug offenses. A first offense for cannabis possession carried 2-10 years and up to $20,000 fine.

US-Narcotics-1956.name: Narcotic Control Act (United States)
US-Narcotics-1956.description: Increased mandatory minimum sentences for drug trafficking to 5 years for first offense and 10 years for subsequent violations. Prohibited judges from suspending sentences or imposing probation for many drug offenses.

US-CSA-1970.name: Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act / Controlled Substances Act (United States)
US-CSA-1970.description: Consolidated all previous federal drug laws into a single statute. Title II (the Controlled Substances Act) established five schedules for classifying drugs based on medical use and abuse potential. Replaced earlier laws and established the legal foundation for modern US drug policy.

US-AntiDrug-1986.name: Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1986 (United States)
US-AntiDrug-1986.description: Major expansion of the War on Drugs. Established mandatory minimum sentences for drug offenses with a 100:1 sentencing disparity between crack and powder cocaine (5g crack = 500g powder). Criminalized money laundering and substantially increased penalties for drug trafficking.

US-AntiDrug-1988.name: Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 (United States)
US-AntiDrug-1988.description: Expanded the 1986 legislation by creating the Office of National Drug Control Policy (Drug Czar). Extended mandatory minimums to drug conspiracy and attempt charges. Made crack cocaine the only drug with mandatory minimum for first offense of simple possession. Authorized $2.8 billion for drug control.
